titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Clayton Eshleman Papers
titlestmt.author: by Jennifer Meehan

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday January 12, 2019 at 04:00

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection consists of material created and accumulated by Clayton Eshleman in the course of his activities as a poet, author, translator, and editor, and primarily documents Eshleman's literary career from circa 1992 to 2008 and the publication of Sulfur magazine from circa 1990 to 2000. Material includes notes, drafts, and manuscripts for Eshleman's works of poetry and prose (published after 1994) and for works translated by Eshleman; proofs for issues 28-45/46 of Sulfur, as well as correspondence, unpublished manuscripts, and other production material; correspondence with authors, poets, and colleagues; notebooks; a computer disk; and other papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Ken Lopez Bookseller on various funds, 2005, 2009, and 2015. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
Boxes 50, 85 (born digital): Restricted fragile materials. Access copies of digital files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Clayton Eshleman Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Clayton Eshleman Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, and competing priorities. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization, upon acquisition. Further organization and description was carried out in 2011. Various acquisitions associated with the collection have not been merged and organized as a whole. Each acquisition is described separately in the contents list below and titled according to month and year of acquisition.

Descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This collection includes material formerly classed as Uncat MSS 836 and Uncat MSS 1193.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Clayton Eshleman
bioghist.p: Clayton Eshleman was born in Indianapolis, Indiana, in 1935. He earned a B.A. in philosophy and an M.A. in creative writing, both from Indiana University. He is the author of numerous collections of poetry and prose, including Under World Arrest (1994), Companion Spider (2002), An Alchemist with One Eye on the Fire (2006), and Reciprocal Distillations (2007), and has translated the work of César Vallejo and Aimé Césaire, among others. He founded and edited the literary magazines Caterpillar (1967-1973) and Sulfur (1981-2000).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of material created and accumulated by Clayton Eshleman in the course of his activities as a poet, author, translator, and editor, and primarily documents Eshleman's literary career from circa 1992 to 2008 and the publication of Sulfur magazine from circa 1990 to 2000. Material includes notes, drafts, and manuscripts for Eshleman's works of poetry and prose (published after 1994) and for works translated by Eshleman; proofs for issues 28-45/46 of Sulfur , as well as correspondence, unpublished manuscripts, and other production material; correspondence with authors, poets, and colleagues; notebooks; a computer disk; and other papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three groupings: December 2005 Acquisition, June 2009 Acquisition, and July 2015 Acquisition.
Material within this collection has been organized by acquisition reflecting the fact that the collection has been acquired in increments over time.

Researchers should note that material within each acquisition overlaps with and/or relates to material found in other acquisitions. For instance, correspondence and writings can be found in both groupings. In order to locate all relevant material within this collection, researchers will need to consult each acquisition described in the Collection Contents section.
Researchers should also note that similar material can be arranged differently in each acquisition, depending on how the material was organized when it was received by the library.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into five series: Sulfur Production Files; Poetry and Prose; Translations; Correspondence and Subject Files; and Other Papers.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original computer disks are restricted. Copies of electronic files are available through Access Services.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Printed email correspondence is arranged alphabetically by surname of correspondent. General correspondence and postcards are arranged in files at the end of the series.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Ken Lopez Bookseller on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2015.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This addition consists of writings, correspondence, printed material, teaching materials, artwork, and other papers by or relating to Clayton Eshleman.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes notes on Tejada's Mirrors for Gold, Israeli invasion of the Gaza Strip, for a class What is a Poet?, Leakey's The Origin of Humankind, review of Neruda's The Grapes and the Wind, The Rhinecliff Station, The Color of Time, notes on Avant-Garde for a 2002 panel, notes on Rhisomic Identities", Stages of Regeneration, Talk on Surrealism, Proteus and Poetic Experiment, notes for a talk on contemporary American poetry, and other materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Articles by archeologists Margaret Conkey, Paul Bahn, Barbara MacLeod, and paleolithic art expert Jean Clottes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Journey Through the Ice Age, M The Man Who Became Caravaggio, The Creative Explosion, Ten Years Under the Earth, Myth From The Ice Age to Mickey Mouse, The Journal the of Charles Olson Archives, Modernism and Negritude, The Time Falling Bodies Take to Light, October #37, and The Mind in the Cave.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Les Cavernes Du Volp, The Cave of Lascaux: The Final Photographs, and Lascaux or the Birth of Art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Beyond Art, Secrets of the Ice Age, and The Cave Artists.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Pan and the Nightmare, The Road to Eleusis, The Cosmic Serpent, Blood Rites, Blood Bread and Roses: How Menstration Created the World, Francis Bacon: Anatomy of An Enigma, The Complete Writings of William Blake, Night Life Night Language, and Sleep and Dreams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include The Gate of Horn, This Tree Grows Out of Hell, Leaves of Grass, The Murder of Christ, Fearful Symmetry, Love's Body, The Wise Wound: Menstration and Everywoman, The Mass Psychology of Fascism, Inter Views: Conversations with Laura Pozzo, Re-Visioning Psychology, The Dream and the Underworld, The Elegy on Hats, Mirrors for Gold, American Poetry Since 1950: Innovators and Outsiders, Shamanism, The Woman's Encycolpedia of Myths and Secrets, The Collected Poems of Wallace Stevens, The Collected Books of Jack Spicer, and The Discovery of The Orgone: The Function of the Orgasm.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Leon Golub: Existential Activist and Painter, Brittany, The Maximus Poems, Twins and the Double, and The Maximus Poems: Volume Three, Maximus Poems: I.V., V., VI.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles include Healing Fiction, two copies of Ghost Dance: The Origins of Religion, Caravaggion, and The Force of Character and the Lasting Life.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Restricted fragile material. Access copies of digial files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
